meanings.def: one or the other of two; it does not matter which
examples: You can park on either side of the street.
You can keep one of the photos. Either of them—whichever you like.
There are two types of qualification—either is acceptable.
Neither candidate was selected for the job.
Neither of my parents speaks/​speak a foreign language.
The offices on either side were empty.
There's a door at either end of the corridor.

meanings.def: used after negative phrases to state that a feeling or situation is similar to one already mentioned
examples: Pete can't go and I can't either.
(especially North American English, informal) ‘I don't like it.’ ‘Me either.’ (= Neither do I).

meanings.def: used to show a choice of two things
examples: Well, I think she's either Czech or Slovak.
I'm going to buy either the blue one or the red one—I can't decide.
Either he could not come or he did not want to.

meanings.def: used to add extra information to a statement
examples: I know a good Italian restaurant. It's not far from here, either.
